Transcribed 16.2.90. To be proof read.
MS letter head: 'LADIES LEICHARDT SEARCH COMMITTEE'. 26/7/65

Allow me, honorable and dear Sir, to draw your attention to the enclosed copy of a letter from Mr Pemberton Walcott of Karri Dale Warren River
MS enclosed with the above letter: 'Extract from a letter of Pemberton Walcott Esq. West Australia | "A certain native whom I could produce offered, & begged to be allowed to conduct me to the remains of 3 white men who he said had - died for want of water he said they were followed and watched in a country destitute of water (the natives obtain it in summer weather by tapping a species of Eucalyptus) for three days that the whites were constantly looking for water & that one died and that to this day there[word missing?] plenty of paper talks ([...]) check word. to be found there. they had no
horses . The locality was about 100 miles to the N. & E. of the Geraldine mine which about N.E. of the Murcheson Murch
i
son? River I do not believe that the natives were harmless spectators from my knowledge I am inclined to think that if there is any foundation for the story that the natives murdered them, I am also of opinion that any Expedition to test the truth of this statement ought to start from Champion Bay commanded by some one who understood the dialect there spoken, and accompanied by natives of that locality it could be very easily accomplished and with very little outlay 3 or 4 months in that direction might yield important results, and possibly open up much country for I am firmly convinced that a belt of good country extends from the Nickol Bay country back of Champion Bay & ditto York & finally reaching the settled parts of Adelaide"'. and ask, whether now when such strenuous efforts are made to ascertain the end of the traveller Leichhardt these efforts could not be seconded by the West Australia Government in
RH: to?
send
RH: send
ing
?
a small party to the spot, indicated by the native as mentioned by Mr Walcott, where a party of whites had fallen. Though it may be but a vague rumour or an invented story, yet while the eastern colonies are doing their share to set the contradictory account of Leichhardts death at rest, the western Colony —
RH: insert 'I'?
anticipate — will gladly share in this work of humanity by enquiry locally. Under any circumstance the general discoveries of a journey such as pointed out, cannot fail to offer a vast recompense for the outlays incurred and no further attention need then be paid to the talk of the native. I am also informed by Mr George Clifton of Dartmoor, that he found also huts and the remnants of firearms at Sharks Bay. The barrel of a gun had been used for knocking oysters from the rocks. It is by no means beyond possibility that this were not the traces of a wrecked sailor but of numbers
members?
of Leichhardts party, who after loosing their horses (perhaps by the [...]
illegible. check.
of N.W. Australia now known) may have walked into Sharks Bay for a chance of relief. As occasional vessels proceed to the spot or perhaps a government vessel may be available for the purpose, the Ladies of the Leichhardt Search Committee would regard it an especial favor if also the origin of these remnants of Europeans at Sharks Bay could by the goodness of your government be ascertained, and if also the account given to Mr Walcott could be trusted.

Perhaps the two enquiries could be combined, for from the locality mentioned by Mr Walcott the party after pursuing the enquiry there might readily descend to Sharks Bay for continuing the search. Mr Clifton informs me, that his successor has in his possession the remains of the firearms brought from Sharks Bay.
I may add, that the Ladies movement has excited a deep interest in some of the highest circles of Europe and that probably towards their enterprise the patronage of many a throne will be extended.

The South Australian promoters of the search have been asked to send a vessel from Adam Bay to Port Essington for the purpose of learning, whether Leichhardt possibly may have proceeded once more to the goal of his former destination without being aware that the settlement was abandoned. The successful efforts made by West Australia to recover the remains of the poor explorers at Roebuck bay reflects great credit on your country. May the same spirit of philanthropy move your government to embark in the enquiry [of the]
RH: after?
Leichhardt, who after all may have reached to within near of your settlement.

It is my intention to attach your honored name to some lovely W. Austr plant, which the next season may bring within my reach for [...].
illegible. check.

MS annotation: 'Dr Mueller written - Enquiries will be made as to truth of Walcott's story which is very improbable. Mr Walcott cannot give name of native but says native Boy "Kingarra" at [...] station knows him. Old guns from Shark's Bay sent to Dr M. - Copy of L. W. Clifton's offl report of 1859 sent.'
